questions.text: A 62-year-old woman was admitted with a retrosternal goiter, which had been discovered during an evaluation for chest discomfort and dyspnea. After routine investigations, including fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) and imaging, the surgical team determined she is at high risk of requiring conversion from a transcervical approach to a median sternotomy. Which of the following conditions would not justify the need for a median sternotomy in this patient?

choices.text: Goiter extending into the posterior mediastinum
Diameter of goiter > Diameter of thoracic inlet
Goiter extending up to the superior margin of the aortic arch

questions.solution:
A goiter extending up to the superior margin of the aortic arch is not a high risk for conversion into open sternotomy. Goiters that extend below the inferior margin of the aortic arch are at high risk of conversion to median sternotomy.

Retrosternal goiter is an extension of the multinodular goiter into the mediastinum. It receives its blood supply from the inferior thyroid arteries and venous drainage through the inferior thyroid veins. This condition is usually asymptomatic and may not require surgery. If the gland enlarges within the thoracic inlet, the pressure may lead to dysphagia, tracheal compression, and eventually airway symptoms. But the majority of retrosternal goiters are asymptomatic or show very few symptoms.

Patients considered for surgery :

  • Significant airway compression
  • Symptoms are present
  • In young patients in whom symptoms are likely to develop

Elderly patients where retrosternal goiters are incidentally found, it observed rather than treated.

>95% of retrosternal goiters can be removed through the transcervical approach.

Retrosternal goiters that are at most risk of requiring conversion to an open sternotomy approach :

  • Malignant cases
  • Revision cases
  • Goiters extending into the posterior mediastinum
  • Diameter of the goiter exceeding that of the thoracic inlet
  • Goiters that reach the carina
  • Goiters that extend below the inferior margin of the aortic arch

If the gland is fixed and immobile or too large to deliver through a cervical approach, a midline sternotomy is performed and the gland can be dissected from below to achieve a safe total thyroidectomy.

questions.text: A patient was brought following blunt abdominal trauma. On examination, he was hemodynamically stable. Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) showed splenic trauma with a subcapsular hematoma over 30% of the surface area. Angiography and embolization were done but failed to achieve hemostasis. Which of the following is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The next step in management is splenorrhaphy. 

The non-expanding subcapsular hematoma over 30% of the surface area is suggestive of grade II splenic injury. These patients are managed by angiography and embolization, and if it fails, the next step in management is a spleen-saving technique or splenorrhaphy.

Splenorrhaphy is a procedure done to preserve the spleen parenchyma. These involve all the surgical procedures done to save the spleen parenchyma while splenectomy is the entire surgical removal of the viscera. Splenorrhaphy should not be performed if the patient is unstable if there are multiple injuries or extensive splenic injury. 

Grades of splenic injury:

Grade Injury
I Non-expanding subcapsular hematoma (<10% of surface area) or laceration, <1 cm of parenchymal depth
II Non-expanding subcapsular hematoma (10-50% of surface area) or laceration, 1-3 cm of parenchymal depth which does not involve the trabecular vessels
III

Hematoma > 50% of surface area or expanding

  • Ruptured subcapsular or parenchymal hematoma,
  • Intraparenchymal hematoma >5 cm or expanding Or
    Laceration, >3 cm parenchymal depth or involving
    trabecular vessels
IV Laceration involving segmental or hilar vessels leading to major devascularization (>25% of the spleen)
V Shattered spleen
or
A hilar vascular injury that devascularizes the spleen.

Management of splenic trauma:

Grade I and II injuries:

They are usually hemodynamically stable and are managed non-operatively. Initially, these patients are managed conservatively with regular monitoring of vitals, hematocrit, and serial CECT.

If the grade of injury is found to increase, then angiography and embolization of the bleeding vessel are done to achieve hemostasis. If angiography and embolization fail to achieve hemostasis, or if the patient becomes hemodynamically unstable, then a splenorrhaphy is done.

Grade III injuries that are hemodynamically stable are managed like that of grades I and II, while those that are hemodynamically unstable are managed like that of grades IV and V.

Grade IV and V injuries patients are usually hemodynamically unstable and splenectomy is done.

Other options: 

Option A: Repeat angiography and embolization are unlikely to help as it has already failed once in this patient. 

Option B: Conservative management will not stop the ongoing hemorrhage that is present in this patient. It is useful in patients who are no longer bleeding. 

Option C: Splenectomy is not required in this patient as they have a grade II injury and are still hemodynamically stable.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

Related Pearl: Indications for Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) in splenic trauma

Indications :

  • Patient younger than 55 years
  • Grade I, II, or III (in selective cases) splenic injury
  • Physiologic stability, as indicated by normal blood pressure, lack of tachycardia, absence of physical examination findings indicating shock, and absence of metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A child is planned for surgical correction of simple congenital ptosis. He has poor levator function. What is the appropriate treatment in this case?
questions.solution:
Frontalis sling suspension is the treatment of choice for congenital ptosis with poor levator function.

Ptosis refers to the drooping of the upper eyelid such that it covers more than 2 mm of the superior cornea. It may be congenital or acquired.

Congenital Ptosis may be classified as:

  • Simple - isolated abnormality
  • Complicated -associated with ocular motor anomalies, blepharophimosis syndrome, and Marcus Gunn ptosis.

When the levator function is poor (3 mm or less), the eyelid is suspended from the frontalis muscle using sutures, a fascia lata sling, or a silicone band. Infection of the suture bed is a complication of this surgery and the suture should be monitored.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida at 39 weeks in active labor requires an episiotomy as the fetal head crowns. The incision is made at a 45-degree angle to the midline. Post-delivery, the patient reports minimal pain. What is the most likely reason for choosing a mediolateral episiotomy over a midline episiotomy in this case?

choices.text: Faster healing time compared to midline episiotomy
Greater protection against involving the anal sphincter
Increased patient comfort during the procedure

questions.solution:
The obstetrician did a mediolateral episiotomy because there is greater protection against involving the anal sphincter in a mediolateral episiotomy.

An episiotomy is an intended incision of the perineum with the goal of enlargement of the vaginal opening for birth. Prior to episiotomy, analgesia is provided by existing labor regional analgesia, bilateral pudendal nerve block, or local infiltration with 1% lignocaine. Typically, an episiotomy is completed when the head is visible during a contraction to a diameter of 4 to 5 cm.

Midline episiotomy begins at the fourchette, incises the perineal body in the midline, and ends well before the external anal sphincter. Mediolateral episiotomy begins at the midline of the fourchette and is directed to the right or left at an angle of 60 degrees off the midline. This angle accounts for the stretch distortion of the perineal anatomy during crowning. After delivery and resolution of the distortion, it ultimately yields an incision 45 degrees from the midline for suturing.

Midline episiotomy Mediolateral episiotomy
Surgical repair is easy Surgical repair is difficult
Blood loss is less Blood loss is more
Healing is superior Healing is not so good
Dyspareunia is rare Dyspareunia is comparatively more

Postoperative pain is less

Postoperative pain is more

Extension, if occurs, may involve the anal sphincter

Extension, even if it occurs, will not involve the anal sphincter

questions.text: Which of the following is a possible complication of this procedure?
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the image is chorionic villus sampling (CVS). Abortion is a possible complication of the procedure.

Chorionic villus sampling:
Study material: Chorionic villi from trophoblastic cells of chorion frondosum
Time: 10 to 13 weeks (transcervically), 10 weeks to term (transabdominally)

The best time to perform chorionic villus sampling is 11–13 weeks.

Indications

  • To detect chromosomal abnormalities such as Down syndrome.
  • To detect inborn errors of metabolism like phenylketonuria.
  • For DNA analysis in hemoglobinopathies, thalassemia, and sickle cell anemia.

Complications: Abortion (CVS> Amniocentesis), limb reduction defects and oro-mandibular defects (when done before 10 weeks)

Drawback: Not suitable for the detection of neural tube defects.

Below is an image showing the procedure of amniocentesis vs chorionic villus sampling.

questions.text: A boy diagnosed with acute otitis media 1 week back, presents with fever, post-auricular pain (image shown), and purulent discharge from his ear. There is mastoid tenderness and the meatus immediately fills with pus when it's cleaned. What is the definitive management for his condition?
questions.solution:
The definitive management of this child who presented with acute mastoiditis and has a positive reservoir sign is a cortical mastoidectomy.

Mastoiditis involves inflammation and infection of the mastoid air cells and often follows acute otitis media. It is characterized by symptoms such as fever, postauricular pain and tenderness, swelling, and ear discharge. A diagnosis can be made through clinical examination, imaging studies like CT scans, and culture of ear discharge to identify causative organisms.

Initial treatment includes antibiotics, but when these and other conservative measures fail, and symptoms persist or worsen, surgical intervention is necessary to prevent further complications such as subperiosteal abscesses, facial nerve paralysis, and intracranial spread. A cortical mastoidectomy, which involves removing the infected air cells within the mastoid bone, draining abscesses, and ensuring adequate aeration of the mastoid cavity, is often the first surgical step aimed at eradicating infection and preventing further complications. 

Indications for Cortical Mastoidectomy:

  • Presence of a subperiosteal abscess
  • Sagging of the posterosuperior meatal wall
  • Positive reservoir sign (meatus immediately fills with pus after it has been mopped out)
  • Lack of improvement or worsening of symptoms despite adequate antibiotic treatment for 48 hours
  • Development of complications from mastoiditis, such as:
  • Facial paralysis
  • Labyrinthitis
  • Intracranial complications (e.g., meningitis, brain abscess)

Other Options:

Option B: While IV antibiotics are initially used, the severity and persistence of symptoms in this case require surgical intervention to prevent further complications.

Option C: Myringotomy involves creating an incision in the tympanic membrane to drain middle ear fluid. It is a less invasive procedure often used in early or uncomplicated cases but insufficient for advanced mastoiditis.

Option D: Radical mastoidectomy is a more extensive procedure involving the removal of more structures within the mastoid and middle ear. It is typically reserved for chronic or recurrent cases where less invasive surgeries have failed.

questions.text: A surgical consultation is requested for a neonate currently in the neonatal intensive care. On examination, the following findings were found along with a bifid uvula. Which of the following is the most appropriate management in this child?

choices.text: Cleft soft palate repair at 9 to 12 months
Cleft lip and soft palate repair at 5 to 6 months
Cleft soft and hard palate repair at 12-15 months

questions.solution:
The most appropriate management for this patient would be cleft lip and soft palate repair at 5 to 6 months. As the neonate in question has a unilateral right-sided cleft lip along with cleft hard and soft palate, the appropriate management for this patient would be (two separate procedures):

  1. Cleft lip and soft palate repair at 5 to 6 months, followed by 
  2. Hard palate repair with or without a revision surgery for the lip and soft palate at 15 to 18 months.

The different types of facial clefts are shown below:

  1. Unilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  2. Bilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  3. Unilateral cleft lip associated with cleft palate
  4. Bilateral cleft lip and palate
  5. Cleft palate only

Clefts of the lip, alveolus, hard and soft palate are the common congenital anomalies of the orofacial structures.

questions.text: You are a resident doctor in the General Surgery Department of a Hospital. You have been given the task of arranging the following surgeries to be posted for tomorrow’s Operation Theatre. Which of the following surgeries will you post first in the OT list
questions.solution:
Right hemithyroidectomy is a Clean Procedure and hence shall occupy the first position in the given list of surgeries.

Cleaner surgeries are posted first in the OT list.

Clean Procedures

  • CABG, Thyroid Sx, Breast Sx ( except abscess), Knee Replacement

Clean contaminated 

  • Gastrointestinal or genitourinary system without inflammation 
  • Eg: Elective appendicectomy, Elective cholecystectomy

Contaminated procedures 

  • GI / GU system with Non purulent inflammation  
  • Eg Same as above in an emergency setting

Dirty wounds 

  • Pus present , Peritonitis , Traumatic wound not managed for > 6 hrs

questions.text:
A 45-year-old female who has an anal fistula is advised for surgery. She browsed about the surgical procedures and came to know that a few procedures may lead to fecal incontinence. She was worried and asks you about the surgeries that does not lead to this complication. Which among the following surgeries allow sphincter preservation?
  1. Video-assisted anal fistula treatment.
  2. Ligation of intersphincteric fistula tract.
  3. Flap advancement.
  4. Fistula tract laser closure.
  5. Over-the-scope clip.
questions.solution:
Out of the given options, 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 surgeries allow sphincter preservation. The surgeries for anal fistula that allow sphincter preservation are:

  • Ligation of intersphincteric fistula tract.
  • Flap advancement.
  • Over-the-scope clip.
  • Video-assisted anal fistula treatment (VAAFT)
  • Fistula tract laser closure (FiLaC)

Ligation of the intersphincteric fistula tract (LIFT) is done at the level of the intersphincteric plane where the internal opening and fistula are disconnected. This is followed by the removal of the residual gland without involving the sphincter complex.

Flap advancement is done for the tracts that are not indurated and adequate intra-anal access can be obtained. The internal opening of the fistula is closed with a well-vascularized flap of anorectal mucosa. This procedure aims at preserving the anatomy and function of the sphincter.

Over-the-scope procedure involves using a nitinol clip and closing the internal opening and disconnecting the external tract. Clip migration and elective removal because of pain are the main complications.

Video-assisted anal fistula treatment (VAAFT) and fistula tract laser closure (FiLaC) are other procedures that allow sphincter preservation.

A fistulotomy is preferred mainly for intersphincteric fistulae and trans-sphincteric fistulae. Here, all structures lying between the external and internal openings are divided. In fistulectomy, the entire fistula tract is removed by diathermy cautery.

questions.text: You are assisting in a tubal sterilization procedure where the senior resident performs the following technique. This procedure is known as:
questions.solution:
The sterilization procedure shown in the above image is Irving's procedure. It involves ligating and excising the mid-portion of the tube after which the proximal stump is buried into the myometrium. The distal stump is buried in the broad ligament.

It is often done in conjunction with caesarian sections. It is a reliable method of sterilization, but not a reversible technique and may require a laparotomy incision.

Other methods of sterilization include:

1. Laparotomy/Minilaparotomy:

  • Pomeroy's procedure: The fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision, and the middle portion is formed into a loop which is tied at the base with catgut and excised. It is surgically reversible.
  • Madlener's procedure: A loop of the fallopian tube is crushed and then ligated with a nonabsorbable suture.
  • Kroener's technique: It refers to fimbriectomy done by ligating the distal ampulla of the tube with two permanent sutures followed by division and removal of the infundibulum. It is irreversible.
  • Uchida's method: The serosa in the midsegment of the tube is stripped off from the mucosa and then excised. The proximal segment is ligated and buried in the broad ligament. The minimum tubal excision preserves the potential for tuboplasty.
  • Cornual resection: The cornual part of the tube is resected between two clamps.

2. Laparoscopic techniques: Each fallopian tube is picked up near the isthmic end (2–3 cm away) and clipped or banded with silastic bands, Filshie clips, Hulka band, or falope silastic rings. It is a reversible technique.

3. Hysteroscopic sterilization with the Essure permanent device: It is made of a flexible stainless steel inner coil and a nickel-titanium outer coil (nitinol). Polyethylene terephthalate (PET) in the inner coil causes a benign local fibrous tissue growth that occludes the fallopian tube. It takes 3 months to occlude the tube, confirmed with hysterosalpingography. During this period of 3 months, other methods of contraception should be used. It is an irreversible technique.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the image given below?

choices.text: It is a drainage procedure for chronic pancreatitis.
Resection of tail with longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy.
Failed due to restenosis and segmental obstruction of the pancreas.
Used in resectable tumors of the body or the tail of the pancreas.

questions.solution:
The image shows the distal resection of the pancreatic tail, with end-to-end pancreaticojejunostomy, i.e., Duval procedure.

Resection of tail with longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy is known as Puestow Procedure.

It is a drainage procedure for chronic pancreatitis (Option A). It was developed on the basis of presumption that a single stricture of duct of Wirsung near the ampulla was responsible for the obstructive pathology and terminal drainage would treat the condition.

It consists of a distal pancreatectomy with roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy. But it almost invariably failed due to restenosis and segmental obstruction of the pancreas due to progressive scarring. (Option C)

Note: This procedure is outdated and not in use due to low improvement rates. It is now used in resectable tumors of the body or the tail of the pancreas. (Option D)

Related Pearl: Drainage procedures for chronic Pancreatitis

Duval procedure: Distal pancreatectomy with Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy

Puestow procedure: Resection of tail followed by longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy

  • Partington and Rochelle modification of Puestow procedure: Elimination of resection of pancreatic tail
  • A longitudinal pancreatotomy typically discloses segmental stenosis of the pancreatic duct and the presence of intraductal calculi in a patient with chronic calcific pancreatitis.
  • Following mobilization of a Roux limb of jejunum, a longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy is performed to permit extensive drainage of the pancreatic duct system.

Related Pearl: Resection and Hybrid Surgical Procedures for Chronic Pancreatitis

Beger’s procedure: Duodenum-preserving pancreatic head resection (DPPHR)

  • The completed resection after transection of the pancreatic neck and subtotal removal of the pancreatic head, with preservation of the distal common bile duct and duodenum (Marked A).
  • Completion of the reconstruction of the anastomosis to the distal pancreas and to the proximal pancreatic rim by the same Roux limb of the jejunum.

Frey’s procedure:

  • The local resection of the pancreatic head with longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (LR-LPJ) provides complete decompression of the entire pancreatic ductal system. Reconstruction is performed with a side-to-side Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy.

Warren’s modification of Beger’s procedure:

Berne modification (Beger + Frey) involves excavation of the central portion of the head without formal division of the neck.

(image below)

Hamburg modification of Frey’s procedure

Note:

Surgical treatments for chronic pancreatitis

Resection

  • Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Kausch–Whipple procedure)
  • Pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy (Traverso–Longmire)
  • Beger procedure
  • Near-total or total pancreatectomy

Decompression/Drainage

  • Duval procedure
  • Puestow–Gillesby procedure
  • Partington–Rochelle procedure (Puestow)
  • Izbicki procedure

Hybrid (resection+decompression)

  • Frey procedure
  • Hamburg modification
  • Berne modification

questions.text: A child presents with pain and swelling in the right side of his scrotum and testicular torsion is suspected. Which is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Immediate exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side
Immediate exploration on symptomatic side only
Delayed exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side
Delayed exploration on symptomatic side only

questions.solution:
In a case of suspected testicular torsion, immediate exploration needs to be done on both the symptomatic as well as the asymptomatic side.

In testicular torsion, the blood supply to the testicle is compromised due to the twisting of the spermatic cord within the tunica vaginalis, resulting in ischemia of the epididymis and the testis.

At the time of surgical exploration contralateral testes also must be explored and fixed to the dartos fascia due to the possibility that the same anatomic defect allowing torsion exists on the contralateral side.

More than 80% of testes can be salvaged if surgery is performed within 6 hours. If the testis is found to be necrosed on scrotal exploration, orchidectomy of the necrosed testis and orchidopexy of the contralateral testis is done.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient, during his routine annual checkup, is found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 40 mm in diameter on USG. Which of the following is true about the management of this patient?

choices.text: Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm
Urgently wheel the patient to OT for surgery
Surgery is indicated only if aneurysm is >77mm

questions.solution:
Surgery is indicated in asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm only if its diameter is more than 55mm.

If the diameter is less than 55mm, regular ultrasound monitoring is required. This is because elective open surgery has a higher rate of mortality when compared to conservative management for aneurysms of size < 55mm.

Management of aortic aneurysm
AAA is surgically managed by dacron graft repair. It can be either open or EVAR.

  • Open surgical repair is done by exposing the aorta through a mid sternal incision and graft replacement. To expose the aorta the descending colon should be mobilized medially and this is known as left visceral rotation or Mattox procedure.
  • EVAR (endovascular aneurysm repair) is a minimally invasive procedure in which an aortic stent graft is placed on the nonaneurysmal aortoiliac segment.

Complications of following abdominal aortic aneurysm repair

  • Cardiovascular (ischemia and infarction)
  • Respiratory (atelectasis or consolidation).
  • Colonic ischemia.
  • Renal failure.
  • Aortoduodenal fistula
  • spinal cord ischemia

questions.text: A male patient was brought to the ER after a road traffic accident. On examination, left-sided hydropneumothorax was noted. Thoracostomy was done and around 1800 ml of blood was drained in 1 hour. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Continue resuscitation for the next 6 Hours
Administer a hemostatic agent through the chest tube

questions.solution:
Given the significant blood loss (1800 ml) and the patient's critical condition, the most appropriate management in this scenario would be an emergency thoracotomy.

A thoracotomy is a surgical procedure in which an incision is made into the chest to access the thoracic cavity. It is performed in critical situations to control bleeding and repair injuries to the chest structures, including the lung and blood vessels.

In this case, the patient's condition is serious due to the combination of pneumothorax, hydrothorax, and a rapid blood loss of 1800 ml in just 1 hour. This level of bleeding suggests a severe injury to blood vessels or vital structures within the chest. Emergency thoracotomy would provide direct access to the bleeding source, allowing for immediate control of bleeding, repair of injuries, and restoration of stable conditions.

Indications for thoracotomy:

  • Initial tube thoracostomy drainage of >1000 ml (penetrating injury) or >1500 ml (blunt injury) of frank blood
  • Ongoing tube thoracostomy drainage of >200 ml/ hr for 3 consecutive hours in non-coagulopathic patients with hemothorax
  • Caked hemothorax despite the placement of two chest tubes
  • Massive air leak from chest tube with inadequate ventilation
  • Open pneumothorax
  • Great vessel injury
  • Pericardial tamponade
  • Cardiac herniation
  • Tracheobronchial injury
  • Esophageal perforation

Other Options:

Option A: Thoracentesis involves the removal of fluid or air from the pleural space using a needle or catheter. However, given the severity of the situation with rapid blood loss, this procedure alone would not adequately address the underlying issues or stop the significant bleeding.

Option B: Continued resuscitation for the next 6 hours is not appropriate in this scenario due to the patient's critical condition and substantial blood loss. Immediate intervention is required to stabilize the patient's condition and address the underlying causes of the blood loss.

Option C: While hemostatic agents can be useful in certain bleeding situations, the rapid blood loss and critical nature of the presented case call for a more immediate and direct approach, such as an emergency thoracotomy, to achieve rapid control of bleeding and prevent further complications.

questions.text: A patient presents to a surgeon with a complaint of bleeding per rectum. On examination, the following finding was seen. The mass did not reduce spontaneously or manually. What is the next step of management done in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above scenario with the image showing a reddish mass protruding out of the anal canal that does not reduce spontaneously or manually is suggestive of grade IV internal hemorrhoids. Surgery is indicated and open hemorrhoidectomy is done in this patient. 

Management of internal hemorrhoids:

  • Bleeding from grade 1 and grade 2 hemorrhoids often improve with the addition of dietary fiber, stool softeners, increased fluid intake, and avoidance of straining.
  • Grade 1, grade 2, and some grade 3 hemorrhoids with only an internal component can be treated with simple procedures like rubber band ligation, sclerotherapy, infrared and laser coagulation, and cryotherapy.
  • Surgery is indicated in: 
    • Internal grade 3 or grade 4 hemorrhoids
    • Hemorrhoids with a significant external component
    • Early-grade hemorrhoids not responding to simple procedures

Surgical procedures used in the removal of internal hemorrhoids are:

  •  Doppler-guided hemorrhoidal artery ligation
  • Open hemorrhoidectomy
  • Closed (Ferguson) hemorrhoidectomy
  • Stapled hemorrhoidopexy

Stapled hemorrhoidopexy (Longo operation) is best suited for patients with second and third-degree hemorrhoids. Here, circumferential rectal mucosectomy is performed using a circular stapler. This technique is associated with higher chances of recurrence. The advantages are it is quick to perform, less painful, and less traumatic. The image below shows stapled hemorrhoidopexy.

Management of external hemorrhoids: 

External hemorrhoids do not require treatment unless they become thrombosed. Acutely thrombosed external hemorrhoids cause intense pain and perianal mass during the first 24 to 72 hours. Patients presenting within 72 hours are treated with excision using an elliptical excision performed under local anesthesia.

Other options:

Option A: If the patient presents to the hospital after 72 hours, then it is treated conservatively with analgesics and a sitz bath. Once the symptoms come down, definitive surgery is performed. 

Option B: Rubber band ligation are done for 1st and 2nd degree internal hemorrhoids. It involves pulling mucosa located 1 to 2 cm proximal to the dentate line into a rubber band applier. The rubber band strangulates the underlying tissue, causing scarring and sloughing off of the mass in a few days. 

Option D: Injection sclerotherapy and rubber band ligation are done for 1st and 2nd degree internal hemorrhoids.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female who was using IUCD for contraception presents in the emergency following two episodes of painless spotting per vagina preceded by amenorrhea for 8 weeks. She complained of lightheadedness and her blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg and the pulse rate is 138 beats/minute, with a positive urine pregnancy test. What should be the management of this patient?

IUCD- Intra-uterine contraceptive device

choices.text: IV fluids followed by oral methotrexate
Stabilizing the patient followed by suction evacuation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario implies a case of hemodynamically unstable ruptured ectopic pregnancy, and the management of this patient would be a laparotomy.

The given clinical scenario strongly indicates a case of ruptured ectopic pregnancy based on several key clinical findings. The patient's history of IUCD usage is significant as it increases the risk of ectopic pregnancy. The presence of amenorrhea for 8 weeks is particularly noteworthy, as clinical manifestations of ectopic pregnancy typically manifest between six to eight weeks after the last normal menstrual period.

The patient's presentation with vaginal bleeding, preceded by amenorrhea of more than 4 weeks, is highly suggestive of an ectopic gestation. This suspicion is further strengthened by a positive urine pregnancy test. Most critically, the patient's unstable vital signs point to internal blood loss, which is a classic presentation of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. The combination of these findings creates a clinical picture that warrants immediate medical attention for suspected ruptured ectopic pregnancy.

An unstable patient with this finding should undergo urgent surgical consultation and exploration ie, laparotomy. It reduces hemorrhage and hemodynamic instability, also giving a better view of the operating field for the surgeon.

Risk factors of tubal ectopic pregnancy:

  • Abnormal tube anatomy
  • Surgeries done on the tubes earlier- previous ectopic, fertility restorative, sterilization.
  • Sexually transmitted diseases causing distortion of tubal architecture
  • Peritubal adhesions
  • Salpingitis isthmica nodosa
  • Congenital anomalies secondary to diethyl stilbesterol exposure 
  • Infertility, Artificial reproductive techniques 
  • Smoking 
  • Intrauterine contraceptive systems 

Other differentials :

  • In Abruptio placenta there is painful vaginal bleeding that is associated with contractions and uterine hypertonicity which have not been mentioned in the question, which is basically a shock scenario due to an underlying a condition.
  •  In Placenta previa the classic presentation is painless, bright red vaginal bleeding that often stops spontaneously and then recurs with labor. The bleeding most likely occurs in 3rd trimester and does not lead to a shock-like condition.
  • In an un-ruptured ectopic pregnancy, there is no history of shock-like symptoms.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with complaints of regurgitation on bending down, gurgling noises from the neck on swallowing, and awakening at night with a feeling of tightness in the throat and a fit of coughing. A barium swallow was done, and findings are given below. What is the most preferred surgical technique for this patient?

choices.text: Transoral endoscopic carbon dioxide laser resection
Endoscopic stapling of the diverticular wall

questions.solution:
The preferred surgical technique for this patient is endoscopic stapling of the diverticular wall. 

The patient presents with symptoms of Zenker’s diverticulum(pharyngeal pouch)- regurgitation on bending down, gurgling noises from the neck on swallowing, and awakening at night with a feeling of tightness in the throat and a fit of coughing.

A pharyngeal pouch is a protrusion of mucosa through Killian’s dehiscence, a weak area of the posterior pharyngeal wall between the oblique fibres of the thyropharyngeus and the transverse fibers of cricopharyngeus at the lower end of the inferior constrictor muscle 

Despite endoscopic stapling being the preferred technique in the management of  Zenker’s diverticulum(pharyngeal pouch), in case of inadequate endoscopic access, open excision of the pouch is performed.     

Other options:

Option A: Transoral endoscopic carbon dioxide laser resection is usually performed in early-stage squamous cell carcinoma(SCC) of the hypopharynx 

Option C: Pharyngoplasty is done in conditions like velopharyngeal dysfunction and sleep apnea. This procedure removes tonsillar tissue, preserving the uvula and soft palate.

Option D: Drainage of the abscess is usually done in cases of retropharyngeal abscess which presents with gross swelling and an abscess pointing beneath the thinned mucosa in the posterior wall of the pharynx. Marked dyspnea, neck rigidity, dysphagia, and croupy cough are some of the presenting symptoms in an acute retropharyngeal abscess.

questions.text: An intern noticed the following findings while removing the catheter in a 30-year-old patient.  A manual reduction was attempted but was unsuccessful and hence a dorsal slit was made. Surgery was planned 3 weeks later.  Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition and the definitive procedure done for this patient?

choices.text: It is precipitated after sexual intercourse
It is associated with dorsal chordee

questions.solution:
The clinical history and the image showing swollen glans are suggestive of paraphimosis and circumcision is the definitive procedure done after 3 weeks. It is not associated with dorsal chordee but can lead to ventral chordee. 

Paraphimosis is a condition in which the retracted prepuceal skin over the glans cannot be placed back as a result of which a ring-like constriction is seen proximal to the corona and prepuceal skin. 

This leads to pain and swelling of the glans. Sexual intercourse and urethral catheterization can precipitate the condition. 

Treatment includes manual reduction of the skin. When it is not possible, a dorsal slit has to be made to relieve the pain and compression along with analgesics and antibiotics. This is followed by circumcision after 3 weeks. Alternatively, Sedation and multiple hyaluronidase injection in 10 ml saline are injected to reduce edema followed by circumcision. 

Circumcision is a surgical procedure which involves cutting the dorsal skin up to the corona later extending it circumferentially and ventrally. 

Indications for circumcision include

  • Religious
  • Phimosis - In this condition, the prepuce cannot be retracted over the glans.
  • Paraphimosis after doing initial dorsal slit
  • Balanitis and balanoposthitis - Balanitis is the inflammation of the glans, whereas balanoposthitis involves both glans and prepuce
  • Early carcinoma of the glans penis or prepuce—Here it is both diagnostic as well as therapeutic
  • Certain sexually transmitted diseases, e.g. herpes infection

Complications:

  • Infection
  • Reactionary hemorrhage - It can be due to slippage of ligature from the frenular artery and dorsal vein
  • Urethral stricture near the external meatus in children
  • Chordee due to removal of excess skin on the ventral aspect-Ventral chordee
  • Priapism can occur rarely

questions.text: A male patient presents to the clinic with complaints of jaundice with clay-colored stools and pruritis. After a detailed radiological and pathological investigations, a 2 cm adenocarcinoma is found at the head of the pancreas. There is no spread to the adjacent structures. What is the preferred surgical management in this patient?
questions.solution:
The preferred surgical management in this patient is pylorus-preserving pancreatoduodenectomy (PPPD), also known as Longmire–Traverso procedure. This procedure involves the removal of the duodenum and the pancreatic head and the distal part of the bile duct.

The original pancreatoduodenectomy, as proposed by Whipple, included resection of the gastric antrum. Preserving the antrum and the pylorus is thought to result in a better physiological outcome, with no difference in survival or recurrence rates. Currently, the pylorus is removed in cases when:

  • entire duodenum has to be removed (e.g. in familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)),
  • tumor encroaches in the first part of the duodenum, or stomach
  • A clear resection margin is not achieved by PPPD

For tumors of the body and tail, distal pancreatectomy is the preferred surgical management.

Other options:

Option A: Whipple's procedure is a complex surgery done for carcinomas involving the head of the pancreas. It is done only in cases when the entire duodenum has to be removed e.g. in familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), tumor encroaches in the first part of the duodenum, or stomach or a clear resection margin is not achieved by pylorus-preserving pancreatoduodenectomy.

Option C: Radical pancreaticoduodenectomy involves removing the head of the pancreas, the first part of the small intestine (duodenum), the gallbladder, and part of the bile duct. It is primarily performed to treat pancreatic cancer and other tumors in the pancreatic head region, though it may also be used for chronic pancreatitis in some cases.

Option D: Cholecystojejunostomy is a surgical bypass procedure that creates a connection between the gallbladder and jejunum. It is done for unresectable pancreatic head tumors causing biliary obstruction, distal common bile duct obstruction and when hepaticojejunostomy is not feasible.

questions.text: Nesbitt procedure is used for _____.
questions.solution:
The most common procedure used in Peyronie’s disease is the Nesbitt procedure.

This corrects the deformity by plicating the opposite side of the deformity, thereby straightening the penis.

Peyronie's disease is characterized by penile deformity, palpable penile plaques within the penis, erectile dysfunction and pain on erection.

Other options:

Option B: Marion's disease is a condition where hypertrophy of internal sphincter leads to bladder outlet obstruction.

Option C: Priapism means persistent erection lasting longer than 4 hours and it is a surgical emergency (in case of ischemic priapism).

Option D: Erectile dysfunction is consistent or recurrent inability to attain and/or maintain a penile erection sufficient for sexual satisfaction, which must persist for a minimum duration of 3 months for clinical diagnosis, except in cases of trauma or surgically-induced erectile dysfunction where the diagnosis can be made immediately.
